title: (x) Seen in many Christian books - Aster Medium {fmiles}
content:
Sorry about the descriptively poor title, but I thought anything was better than “Please help me identify this font.”

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202052913im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/unknowntype_5363.jpg)

 [‹ "A New City Guide" Font](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202052913/http:/www.typophile.com/node/21315 "Go to previous forum topic") [It's like Garamond, but it's not ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202052913/http:/www.typophile.com/node/21316 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Peter G.

comments.content: I don’t think it’s Bookman. More like Palatino or Times.

I agree with the ID — good eye ’fmiles’, and I applaud Peter for avoiding ’Identify this font’. I wish more folks would read the instructions.

- Mike Yanega

Yep, It’s definitely Aster:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202052913im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/typeid_4239.gif)
  
Anyone know why it costs $35 at [MyFonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202052913/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/aster/ "See it at MyFonts.com") and $103 at [Veer](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202052913/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=EFT0000019 "See it at Veer")?

Looks like veer sells 3 weights in a bundle while Myfonts sells each weight separately. But that’s just a guess.

And Typophile-sponsor Fontshop [sells it from 17,50 $](http://web.archive.org/web/20081202052913/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=verity.search&font_categories=1&font_categories_search=font_name_search&searchstr=aster)each style. :-D
